title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Facilitative Supervision
description: Test your understanding of the core concepts, definitions, and principles distinguishing facilitative supervision from traditional methods.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines 'Facilitative Supervision'?

options.text: An inspection process focusing on finding faults and punishing non-compliant staff.
A process of guiding, monitoring, and coaching to promote compliance with standards and quality care.
A management function strictly limited to hiring and discharging employees.
A theoretical approach that ignores administrative tasks.

questions.explanation: Facilitative supervision is defined as a process of guiding, monitoring, and coaching workers to promote compliance with standards of practice and assure the delivery of quality care services.
questions.hint: Think about guidance and quality improvement rather than inspection.

questions.question: Select the key principles of Facilitative Supervision from the list below: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Focus on the performance not the person

questions.explanation: Facilitative supervision principles include focusing on performance, being objective/transparent, maintaining confidentiality, and focusing on the future/planning.
questions.hint: Consider what builds trust and improvement.

questions.question:
Review the comparison statement below:

'Traditional supervision emphasizes the past, whereas Facilitative supervision focuses on helping staff improve for the future.'

Is this statement True or False?
questions.explanation: Traditional supervision often dwells on past faults, while facilitative supervision is future-oriented and developmental.
questions.hint: Does facilitative supervision look forward or backward?

questions.question: Supervision is concerned with three main functions of management: ___BLANK___, Guiding, and Controlling.
questions.explanation: The three main functions are Directing, Guiding, and Controlling.
questions.hint: It starts with 'D' and means giving instructions or orders.

questions.question: Analyze the comparison table below. Which characteristic is INCORRECTLY matched?

richContent.content:
FeatureFacilitativeTraditional
FocusProcessesIndividuals
NatureObjectiveSuperficial
TimingRandom/UnplannedTimely
ApproachProblem-solvingFault-finding

questions.explanation: The table incorrectly swaps the timing characteristics. Facilitative supervision is Timely, whereas Traditional supervision is often Random/Not timely.

questions.question: Which of the following are qualities of a good facilitative supervisor? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Good supervisors are good listeners, empathetic, inspiring, and flexible. They do not focus on fault-finding or rigidity.

questions.question: What is the term for the supervisory function that focuses on the professional development of the supervisee?
questions.explanation: The Educative (or Formative) function concerns the professional development of the supervisee.
questions.hint: It relates to education or forming skills.

questions.question: Match the function of supervision to its primary focus:
questions.hint: Think about what each term implies: Education, Support, Administration.

questions.question: Facilitative supervision creates resentment and suspicion among team members.
questions.explanation: False. Traditional supervision creates resentment. Facilitative supervision strengthens relationships and team work.

questions.question: A supervisor who emphasizes the past rather than the future and is critical/punitive is practicing which type of supervision?
questions.explanation: Traditional supervision is characterized by being punitive, fault-finding, and focused on the past.
questions.hint: It's the old way of doing things.
